Award.AwardTitle: News Media Coverage and the Dynamics of Contention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES: 0958743
Gregory M. Maney
Hofstra University

This project compares two cases of ethno-nationalist contention (patterns of action and reaction between authorities, challengers, and their opponents): the early stages of the Troubles in Northern Ireland and the first Palestinian Intifada. The investigators identify: (1) distinct effects upon contention of different types of media outlets; (2) types of coverage that promote escalation or de-escalation of political violence; (3) contextual factors influencing coverage, and (4) ways that interpretive disputes may contribute to conflict. The investigators link qualitative data on event coverage by multiple media sources with quantitative data on levels, forms, agents, and targets of contention.

BROADER IMPACTS: This study advances the fields of peace and conflict, social movements, and political communication. Theoretically, it develops a framework that specifies the relationship between media coverage and contention. Methodologically, it assesses hypotheses in an innovative way that is nuanced (investigating possible contrasting roles played by different types of media outlets), comparative (examining coverage across two political contexts), longitudinal (accounting for different stages of contention), and interactive (inclusive of multiple actors). By analyzing the distinct effects of different types of media coverage across political contexts, the results will assist policy makers, journalists, and activists in recognizing when and how their framing of political events impacts the dynamics of contention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project deepens understanding of the relationship between news coverage and the dynamics of ethno-nationalist contention by examining two cases—the early Troubles in Northern Ireland (1968-1974) and the first Palestinian Intifada (1987-1993). We hypothesized that the news coverage and contention influence each other in three ways: (1) by contributing to highly salient, polarized understandings and meaning-making of political opportunity and threat; (2) by raising the visibility of specific actors, claims, and forms of contention; and (3) by influencing perceptions regarding the legitimacy of different actors, claims, and forms of contention. To test these hypotheses, the investigators collected archived news coverage of collective ethno-nationalist contentious events (herein CENCEs) as well as instances of CENCE from non-media sources. Even separately, the news coverage database and the contentious events database are unique in their level of detail, the number of sources used, and the chronological scope of their coverage. Our merger of these databases advances the discipline by allowing for an empirical assessment of the relationship between collective meaning-making and contentious collective action. Quantitative and qualitative analyses of the data to date support the hypothesized causal mechanisms.

The project makes important intellectual contributions to the fields of collective behavior and social movements (herein CBSM) and peace, war, and social conflict (herein PWSC). First, the project combines political process theory and framing analysis to conceptualize mechanisms whereby collective processes of meaning-making and action influence one another. Second to assess these mechanisms, the project links data on event coverage by multiple news sources with non-media data on levels, forms, agents, and targets of contention. Through these innovations, the project bridges a major analytical divide between scholars focusing alternatively and exclusively upon culturally-laden and structurally-laden factors. Third, CBSM scholars have devoted considerable attention to factors influencing news coverage of protest events. The project takes the field in a new direction by also examining when and how news coverage influences subsequent actions by movements, opponents, and authorities. Fourth, PWSC scholars disagree over the relationship between news coverage and the dynamics of ethno-nationalist contention. The project addresses the debate in a way that is nuanced (investigating possible contrasting roles played by different types of news outlets), comparative (examining news coverage across two political contexts), longitudinal (accounting for different stages of contention), and interactive (inclusive of multiple parties and actors). Fifth, the project develops a see-saw model of perceived political opportunity and threat that highlights the importance of both inter-group and intra-group interpretive disputes to the dynamics of contention. Sixth, we have found that movement-based news outlets often exert greater influence over the actions of non-state actors than mainstream outlets. The findings call into question the emphasis placed by scholars and practitioners upon the role of the mainstream media. The results have reached scholars through peer reviewed academic journals, book chapters, guest lectures, and conference presentations spanning the fields of social movements, mass communication, and conflict transformation.

The project’s broader goals include identifying news reporting practices that influence political violence and conflict transformation. By analyzing the distinct effects of different types of news outlets’ coverage across political contexts, the results assist policy makers, journalists, and activists in recognizing the effects of their rhetoric and emotional expressive reactions. Lesson briefs providing recommendations for best peacebuilding practices are being developed, aimed separately at state officials, journalists, and activists. This project continues the researchers’ proven records of publishing in popular and accessible media and of making community presentations, thus sharing the outcomes widely and with underserved populations.

The PI teaches at a university with an ethnically diverse student body. The co-PI teaches at a university whose members are directly impacted by ethno-nationalist contention and includes students from both nationalities. Both have used project data in their courses. The project has also contributed to the research skills and experience of the undergraduate students and graduate students working on the project. A research assistant collecting data on the early Troubles has spent a significant amount of time in Israel. Learning about the early Troubles has nuanced the assistant’s understanding of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. With regards to Israel and the contested and disputed Territories where ordinary people actually live the conflict on a day-to-day basis, the research assistants are offered a rare opportunity to gain valuable contextual information on earlier stages of the conflict. By bringing together Israeli-Palestinians, Israeli-Jews, and Israeli-Jews who reside in the contested and disputed Territories, the research project provides a rare opportunity for the research assistants to learn about the other side's perceptions and actions as well as to work together in the pursuit of a shared objective.
